name: Acne
description: Acne is a skin condition where hair follicles become clogged with oil and dead skin cells, leading to pimples, blackheads, or whiteheads. It commonly appears on the face, chest, back, and shoulders.
homeCare:
Wash your face twice daily with a gentle cleanser.

Avoid scrubbing or picking at pimples.

Use oil-free, non-comedogenic skincare products.

Keep hair clean and away from the face.
medications:
Benzoyl Peroxide: Apply a thin layer once or twice daily.

Side Effects: Dryness, redness, peeling.

Salicylic Acid: Use as directed on the product label.

Side Effects: Mild stinging or skin irritation.

Topical Retinoids (e.g., Tretinoin, Adapalene): Apply once daily at night.

Side Effects: Dryness, redness, increased sensitivity to sunlight.

Oral Antibiotics (e.g., Doxycycline, Minocycline): Take as prescribed by your doctor.

Side Effects: Stomach upset, increased sun sensitivity.

Isotretinoin: Prescribed by a dermatologist; requires close monitoring.

Side Effects: Dry skin, birth defects if taken during pregnancy, mood changes.
lifestyle:
Maintain a balanced diet rich in fruits and vegetables.

Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water.

Manage stress through relaxation techniques like meditation or yoga.

Ensure adequate sleep to support skin health.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If over-the-counter treatments aren't effective after several weeks.

If acne is severe, painful, or causing emotional distress.

If you develop nodules or cysts

name: Arthritis
description: Arthritis refers to inflammation of one or more joints, causing pain and stiffness that can worsen with age. The most common types are osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
homeCare:
Apply warm or cold compresses to affected joints.

Engage in gentle exercises like walking or swimming.

Maintain a healthy weight to reduce joint stress.

Use assistive devices to ease joint strain.
medications:
Acetaminophen: 500 mg every 4–6 hours as needed.

Side Effects: Liver damage if overused.

NSAIDs (e.g., Ibuprofen): 400–800 mg every 6–8 hours.

Side Effects: Stomach upset, increased risk of bleeding.

Topical Analgesics: Apply as directed to relieve localized pain.
lifestyle:
Incorporate anti-inflammatory foods like fruits and vegetables.

Practice stress-reducing techniques such as meditation.

Ensure adequate sleep to help manage pain.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If joint pain persists or worsens.

If you experience swelling, redness, or warmth around joints.

If over-the-counter medications don't provide relief.

name: Bronchial Asthma
description: Asthma is a chronic condition where the airways narrow and swell, producing extra mucus, leading to difficulty in breathing, coughing, and wheezing.
homeCare:
Identify and avoid asthma triggers like smoke or pollen.

Use a peak flow meter to monitor breathing.

Follow an asthma action plan as prescribed.
medications:
Short-acting bronchodilators (e.g., Albuterol): 2 puffs every 4–6 hours as needed.

Side Effects: Tremors, nervousness.

Inhaled corticosteroids (e.g., Fluticasone): 1–2 puffs daily.

Side Effects: Hoarseness, oral thrush.
lifestyle:
Maintain a clean environment to reduce allergens.

Engage in regular, moderate exercise.

Practice breathing exercises to strengthen lungs.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If asthma symptoms become more frequent or severe.

If medications are less effective.

If you experience shortness of breath during minimal activity.

name: Cervical Spondylosis
description: Cervical spondylosis is age-related wear and tear affecting the spinal disks in your neck, leading to neck pain and stiffness.
homeCare:
Apply heat or cold packs to the neck.

Perform neck exercises to maintain flexibility.

Maintain good posture.
medications:
NSAIDs (e.g., Ibuprofen): 400–800 mg every 6–8 hours.

Side Effects: Stomach upset, increased risk of bleeding.

Muscle relaxants (e.g., Cyclobenzaprine): 5–10 mg three times daily.

Side Effects: Drowsiness, dry mouth.
lifestyle:
Use ergonomic furniture.

Avoid activities that strain the neck.

Incorporate neck-strengthening exercises.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If neck pain persists or worsens.

If you experience numbness or weakness in limbs.

If pain interferes with daily activities.

name: Chicken pox
description: Chickenpox is a contagious viral infection causing an itchy rash and red spots or blisters all over the body.
homeCare:
Keep skin clean and dry.

Use calamine lotion to soothe itching.

Trim fingernails to prevent skin infections from scratching.
medications:
Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine): 25–50 mg every 6–8 hours.

Side Effects: Drowsiness, dry mouth.

Acetaminophen: 500 mg every 4–6 hours for fever.

Side Effects: Liver damage if overused.
lifestyle:
Stay hydrated.

Rest adequately.

Avoid contact with others to prevent spreading.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If the rash spreads to the eyes.

If you experience dizziness, shortness of breath, or vomiting.

If the blisters become infected.

name: Common Cold
description: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, primarily affecting the nose and throat. It's usually harmless, with symptoms resolving within a week or two.
homeCare:
Rest and stay hydrated.

Use saline nasal sprays to relieve congestion.

Gargle with warm salt water to soothe a sore throat.

Use a humidifier to keep air moist.
medications:
Acetaminophen: 500 mg every 4–6 hours for fever and aches.

Side Effects: Liver damage if overused.

Decongestants (e.g., Pseudoephedrine): As directed for nasal congestion.

Side Effects: Insomnia, increased blood pressure.
lifestyle:
Wash hands frequently to prevent spread.

Avoid close contact with sick individuals.

Maintain a healthy diet to support the immune system.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If symptoms last more than 10 days.

If you experience high fever or shortness of breath.

If symptoms worsen after initial improvement.

name: Dengue
description: Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection causing flu-like symptoms, including high fever, severe headaches, and joint pain. Severe cases can lead to bleeding and low platelet counts.
homeCare:
Rest and stay hydrated.

Use mosquito nets and repellents to prevent bites.

Monitor for warning signs like bleeding or persistent vomiting.
medications:
Acetaminophen: 500 mg every 4–6 hours for fever and pain.

Side Effects: Liver damage if overused.

Avoid NSAIDs like ibuprofen and aspirin due to bleeding risk.
lifestyle:
Eliminate standing water to reduce mosquito breeding.

Wear long-sleeved clothing.

Stay indoors during peak mosquito hours.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If you experience severe abdominal pain, bleeding, or difficulty breathing.

If symptoms worsen after initial improvement.

If you have underlying health conditions.

name: Dimorphic Hemorrhoids
description: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the lower rectum or anus, causing discomfort, itching, and bleeding. They can be internal or external.
homeCare:
Take warm sitz baths several times a day.

Use over-the-counter hemorrhoid creams.

Avoid straining during bowel movements.
medications:
Topical Hydrocortisone: Apply as directed to reduce inflammation.

Side Effects: Skin thinning with prolonged use.

Stool Softeners (e.g., Docusate Sodium): 100 mg once or twice daily.

Side Effects: Stomach cramps, diarrhea.
lifestyle:
Increase fiber intake through diet or supplements.

Stay hydrated.

Exercise regularly to prevent constipation.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If bleeding persists.

If hemorrhoids become very painful or don't improve with home treatment.

If you notice a lump near the anus that doesn't go away.

name: Fungal Infection
description: Fungal infections can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, nails, and mucous membranes, leading to symptoms like itching, redness, and scaling.
homeCare:
Keep the affected area clean and dry.

Avoid sharing personal items like towels.

Wear breathable clothing.
medications:
Topical Antifungals (e.g., Clotrimazole): Apply twice daily.

Side Effects: Skin irritation.

Oral Antifungals (e.g., Fluconazole): 150 mg once weekly for 2–4 weeks.

Side Effects: Liver toxicity, gastrointestinal upset.
lifestyle:
Change socks and underwear daily.

Use antifungal powders if prone to infections.

Maintain good hygiene.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If the infection doesn't improve with over-the-counter treatments.

If the infection spreads or becomes more severe.

If you have a weakened immune system.

name: Hypertension
description: Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a condition where the force of the blood against artery walls is consistently too high, potentially leading to heart disease and stroke.
homeCare:
Monitor blood pressure regularly.

Reduce sodium intake.

Limit alcohol consumption
medications:
ACE Inhibitors (e.g., Lisinopril): 10–40 mg once daily.

Side Effects: Cough, elevated blood potassium levels.

Beta-Blockers (e.g., Metoprolol): 50–100 mg twice daily.

Side Effects: Fatigue, cold hands.
lifestyle:
Engage in regular physical activity.

Maintain a healthy weight.

Manage stress through relaxation techniques.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If blood pressure readings consistently exceed 130/80 mmHg.

If you experience symptoms like headaches, chest pain, or vision changes.

If you have other risk factors like diabetes or kidney disease.

name: Migraine
description: A migraine is a neurological condition characterized by intense, throbbing headaches, often on one side of the head. It may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.
homeCare:
Rest in a quiet, dark room.

Apply a cold compress to the forehead.

Practice relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation.
medications:
Over-the-counter pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen): 200–400 mg every 4–6 hours.

Side Effects: Stomach upset, dizziness.

Triptans (e.g., Sumatriptan): 50–100 mg at onset of migraine.

Side Effects: Tingling, flushing, drowsiness.
lifestyle:
Maintain a regular sleep schedule.

Stay hydrated and avoid skipping meals.

Identify and avoid migraine triggers.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If migraines are frequent or severe.

If over-the-counter medications are ineffective.

If migraines are accompanied by neurological symptoms.

name: Pneumonia
description: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which may fill with fluid, causing cough, fever, and difficulty breathing.
homeCare:
Get plenty of rest.

Stay hydrated.

Use a humidifier to ease breathing.
medications:
Antibiotics (for bacterial pneumonia): As prescribed by a doctor.

Side Effects: Nausea, diarrhea.

Over-the-counter pain relievers (e.g., Acetaminophen): 500 mg every 4–6 hours.

Side Effects: Liver damage if overused.
lifestyle:
Avoid smoking and exposure to pollutants.

Practice good hygiene to prevent infection.

Get vaccinated against pneumonia and influenza.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing high fever, chest pain, or persistent cough.

If breathing becomes difficult.

If symptoms worsen despite home care.

name: Psoriasis
description: Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune condition that causes rapid skin cell turnover, leading to thick, red, scaly patches on the skin.
homeCare:
Keep skin moisturized.

Take regular baths with bath oils or oatmeal.

Avoid triggers like stress and skin injuries.
medications:
Topical corticosteroids: Apply as directed to reduce inflammation.

Side Effects: Skin thinning with prolonged use.

Vitamin D analogs (e.g., Calcipotriene): Apply as prescribed.

Side Effects: Skin irritation.
lifestyle:
Maintain a healthy diet and weight.

Limit alcohol consumption.

Manage stress through relaxation techniques.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If psoriasis covers large areas of the body.

If experiencing joint pain or stiffness.

If over-the-counter treatments are ineffective.

name: Typhoid
description: Typhoid fever is a bacterial infection caused by Salmonella typhi, leading to high fever, weakness, stomach pain, and loss of appetite.
homeCare:
Ensure adequate rest.

Stay hydrated with clean fluids.

Maintain good personal hygiene.
medications:
Antibiotics (e.g., Ciprofloxacin): As prescribed by a doctor.

Side Effects: Nausea, diarrhea.

Antipyretics (e.g., Paracetamol): 500 mg every 4–6 hours for fever.

Side Effects: Liver damage if overused.
lifestyle:
Eat a nutritious, easily digestible diet.

Avoid raw or undercooked foods.

Practice safe food and water consumption.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing high fever or severe abdominal pain.

If symptoms persist or worsen.

If there's a history of exposure to contaminated food or water.

name: Varicose Veins
description: Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted veins commonly appearing in the legs due to weakened valves and veins.
homeCare:
Elevate legs when resting.

Wear compression stockings.

Avoid prolonged standing or sitting.
medications:
Topical creams (e.g., Horse chestnut extract): Apply as directed to reduce swelling.

Side Effects: Skin irritation.

Pain relievers (e.g., Ibuprofen): 200–400 mg every 4–6 hours.

Side Effects: Stomach upset, dizziness.
lifestyle:
Engage in regular physical activity.

Maintain a healthy weight.

Avoid tight clothing that restricts blood flow.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If varicose veins cause pain or discomfort.

If skin ulcers or sores develop near the veins.

If there's swelling or redness in the legs.

name: Allergy
description: An allergy is an immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to your body, such as pollen, pet dander, or certain foods.
homeCare:
Avoid known allergens.

Keep windows closed during high pollen seasons.

Use air purifiers to reduce indoor allergens.
medications:
Antihistamines (e.g., Loratadine): 10 mg once daily.

Side Effects: Drowsiness, dry mouth.

Nasal corticosteroids (e.g., Fluticasone): 1–2 sprays in each nostril daily.

Side Effects: Nasal irritation, nosebleeds.
lifestyle:
Shower and change clothes after outdoor activities.

Regularly clean bedding and vacuum carpets.

Monitor pollen forecasts and limit outdoor exposure when counts are high.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If allergy symptoms interfere with daily activities.

If over-the-counter medications are ineffective.

If experiencing severe reactions like difficulty breathing.

name: Diabetes
description: Diabetes is a chronic condition that affects how your body turns food into energy, leading to high blood sugar levels.
homeCare:
Monitor blood sugar levels regularly.

Follow a balanced diet rich in fiber and low in sugar.

Engage in regular physical activity.
medications:
Metformin: 500–1000 mg twice daily.

Side Effects: Nausea, diarrhea.

Insulin therapy: Dosage as prescribed by a doctor.

Side Effects: Low blood sugar, weight gain.
lifestyle:
Maintain a healthy weight.

Avoid smoking and limit alcohol consumption.

Manage stress through relaxation techniques.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing symptoms like frequent urination, excessive thirst, or unexplained weight loss.

If blood sugar levels are consistently high or low.

If experiencing complications like vision problems or numbness in extremities.

name: Drug Reaction
description: A drug reaction occurs when the body responds adversely to a medication. Reactions can range from mild rashes to severe conditions like anaphylaxis.
homeCare:
Stop taking the suspected medication immediately.

Apply cool compresses to alleviate skin reactions.

Use over-the-counter antihistamines for mild symptoms.
medications:
Antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine): 25–50 mg every 4–6 hours.

Side Effects: Drowsiness, dry mouth.

Corticosteroids (e.g., Prednisone): Dosage as prescribed by a doctor.

Side Effects: Weight gain, mood swings.
lifestyle:
Wear medical alert identification.

Inform healthcare providers about known drug allergies.

Keep a list of medications that have caused reactions.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing difficulty breathing or swelling of the face and throat.

If symptoms worsen or new symptoms appear.

If over-the-counter treatments are ineffective.

name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease
description: GERD is a chronic condition where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing heartburn and other symptoms.
homeCare:
Eat smaller meals and avoid eating before bedtime.

Elevate the head of the bed.

Avoid trigger foods like spicy or fatty foods.
medications:
Antacids (e.g., Tums): Take as needed for symptom relief.

Side Effects: Constipation or diarrhea.

Proton Pump Inhibitors (e.g., Omeprazole): 20 mg once daily.

Side Effects: Headache, nausea.
lifestyle:
Maintain a healthy weight.

Avoid smoking and alcohol.

Wear loose-fitting clothing.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing chest pain or difficulty swallowing.

If symptoms persist despite treatment.

If over-the-counter medications are needed more than twice a week.

name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
description: Peptic ulcers are open sores that develop on the lining of the stomach, upper small intestine, or esophagus, often due to H. pylori infection or long-term use of NSAIDs.
homeCare:
Avoid NSAIDs and alcohol.

Eat a balanced diet and avoid spicy foods.

Manage stress through relaxation techniques.
medications:
Proton Pump Inhibitors (e.g., Omeprazole): 20–40 mg once daily.

Side Effects: Headache, diarrhea.

Antibiotics (e.g., Amoxicillin): As prescribed for H. pylori infection.

Side Effects: Nausea, allergic reactions.
lifestyle:
Quit smoking.

Limit caffeine intake.

Eat meals at regular intervals.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing severe abdominal pain.

If vomiting blood or having black stools.

If symptoms persist despite treatment.

name: Urinary Tract Infection
description: A UTI is an infection in any part of the urinary system, commonly the bladder and urethra, causing symptoms like a strong urge to urinate and a burning sensation during urination.
homeCare:
Drink plenty of water to flush out bacteria.

Avoid irritants like caffeine and alcohol.

Use a heating pad to alleviate discomfort.
medications:
Antibiotics (e.g., Nitrofurantoin): As prescribed by a doctor.

Side Effects: Nausea, headache.

Pain relievers (e.g., Phenazopyridine): As directed for urinary pain.

Side Effects: Orange-colored urine, dizziness.
lifestyle:
Urinate frequently and after sexual activity.

Wipe from front to back after using the toilet.

Wear breathable cotton underwear.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If experiencing fever, chills, or back pain.

If symptoms persist or worsen.

If UTIs occur frequently.

name: Impetigo
description: Impetigo is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection, most common in young children but can affect people of any age. It causes red sores that quickly rupture, ooze for a few days, and then form a yellowish-brown crust. The infection often occurs around the nose and mouth but can spread to other areas of the body through touch, clothing, or towels.
homeCare:
Gently wash the affected areas with warm water and mild soap.

Avoid scratching or touching the sores to prevent spreading.

Keep fingernails short and clean.

Wash hands frequently and maintain good hygiene.

Do not share personal items like towels, clothing, or bedding.
medications:
Topical Antibiotics:

Mupirocin (Bactroban): Apply a thin layer to the affected area three times daily for 5–10 days.

Side Effects: Skin irritation, itching, burning sensation.

Retapamulin (Altabax): Apply twice daily for 5 days.

Side Effects: Redness, itching at the application site.

Oral Antibiotics (for extensive or resistant cases):

Cephalexin: 250–500 mg every 6 hours for 7 days.

Side Effects: Nausea, diarrhea, allergic reactions.

Dicloxacillin: 250–500 mg every 6 hours for 7 days.

Side Effects: Upset stomach, rash, yeast infections.
lifestyle:
Maintain good personal hygiene.

Wash clothes, towels, and bedding regularly in hot water.

Avoid close contact with others until the infection has healed or after 24–48 hours of antibiotic treatment.

Clean and cover any cuts or abrasions promptly.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If sores are spreading rapidly or not improving with home care.

If you develop a fever or swollen lymph nodes.

If the infection recurs frequently.

name: Jaundice
description: Jaundice is a condition characterized by yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes due to elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood. It is often a sign of underlying issues with the liver, gallbladder, or pancreas, such as hepatitis, gallstones, or liver disease.
homeCare:
Increase fluid intake to help flush out toxins.

Consume a balanced diet rich in fruits and vegetables.

Avoid alcohol and substances that can harm the liver.

Rest adequately to support the body's healing processes.
medications:
For Hepatitis-Induced Jaundice:

Antiviral Medications: As prescribed by a healthcare provider.

Side Effects: Vary depending on the specific medication.

For Bile Duct Obstruction:

Surgical Intervention or Endoscopic Procedures: To remove blockages.

For Hemolytic Anemia:

Corticosteroids: Dosage as directed by a doctor.

Side Effects: Weight gain, mood swings, increased blood sugar.
lifestyle:
Maintain a healthy weight through diet and exercise.

Avoid medications and substances that can damage the liver.

Regularly monitor liver function if at risk.

Get vaccinated against hepatitis A and B.
whenToSeeDoctor:
If you notice yellowing of the skin or eyes.

If you experience dark urine, pale stools, or abdominal pain.

If you have unexplained weight loss or fatigue.

If you have a history of liver disease or are at risk.

name: Malaria
description: Malaria is a serious and sometimes fatal disease caused by a parasite transmitted through the bites of infected mosquitoes. It is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions. Symptoms include high fever, chills, sweating, headaches, nausea, vomiting, and muscle pain.
homeCare:
Rest and stay hydrated to help your body fight the infection.

Use antipyretics like acetaminophen to reduce fever (as directed).

Avoid strenuous activities until fully recovered.
medications:
First-Line Treatments:

Artemisinin-based Combination Therapies (ACTs): Dosage depends on specific medication and patient factors.

Side Effects: Nausea, dizziness, loss of appetite.

Other Antimalarials:

Chloroquine: Dosage as prescribed, depending on resistance patterns.

Side Effects: Blurred vision, itching, gastrointestinal discomfort.

Mefloquine: Dosage as directed by a healthcare provider.

Side Effects: Sleep disturbances, mood changes, dizziness.
lifestyle:
Use insect repellent and sleep under mosquito nets in endemic areas.

Wear protective clothing to reduce mosquito bites.

Take prescribed prophylactic antimalarial medications when traveling to high-risk areas.

Stay indoors during peak mosquito activity times (dusk and dawn).
whenToSeeDoctor:
If you develop a high fever after visiting or living in a malaria-endemic area.

If you experience symptoms like chills, sweating, and muscle aches.

If symptoms worsen or do not improve with initial treatment.
